awd_titl_txt: CAREER:Quantifying Radiation Damage in Metals with Wigner Energy Spectral Fingerprints
awd_abstract_narration:
Non-Technical 

The concept of "damage" to a metal remains difficult to quantify. Metals are among our most important structural materials, providing the backbone to everything from buildings, to bridges, to nuclear reactors. If we had a universal way to measure damage, we would be able to better predict when metals would fail, measure their degradation during service, and design new metals to be both longer-lasting and more economical. The use of stored energy fingerprints is proposed as a way to quantify damage to metals from any damaging process. We focus on radiation damage as an ideal way to make all the types of defects found in metals. A two-pronged experimental and simulation approach will be used to quantify and understand these stored energy fingerprints, relating them directly to the defects created by damage. Immediate applications of this work range from reconciling the differences between ion and neutron irradiation, to predicting material property changes due to radiation damage, to verifying the historical usage of uranium enrichment centrifuges. This enhanced understanding will also be the key to lowering the barriers to its study, creating completely new opportunities for both hands-on instruction and inclusion of more underrepresented minority (URM) students into what is currently one of the least diverse fields in STEM.

Technical  

Our ability to understand how materials respond to damage is limited by our lack of understanding about the precise populations of microstructural defects created during damage processes. Nowhere is this issue more prevalent than in the field of radiation materials science, where the lack of a measurable unit of radiation damage continues to obfuscate the quantitative mechanisms responsible for the degradation of material properties under ionizing irradiation. Were the full populations of every defect in a damaged material to be known, then its material properties could be predicted with existing structure-property relations. We propose to use stored energy fingerprints to visualize the full plethora of defects resulting from damage of any kind, particularly irradiation. We draw inspiration from a long-neglected  idea  stating that radiation damage should store energy like amorphization or cold work. This idea is extended to describe all forms of microstructural damage in metals, in a measurable way which reveals the defects responsible. Using time-accelerated parallel replica dynamics simulations and ultra-fast nanocalorimetric measurements, we will directly link simulated and measured stored energy releases at the mesoscale, with atomistic understanding. This will enable a posteriori measurements of stored energy fingerprints of damaged metals, revealing the atomic configurations and quantities of defects responsible. Thus we seek to provide the full picture of defects resulting from damage, demonstrate a method to measure them, explain their evolution using atomistic simulations, and create unifying theories to predict the defect structures and resultant material properties resulting from damage in metals.

por.por_cntn:
In this project, we were able to conclusively test our core hypothesis that radiation damage is directly measurable using stored energy fingerprints. By using a combination of highly sensitive calorimetry (energy vs. temperature) measurements, electron microscopy, and large-scale atomistic simulations, we were able to uncover the full suite of defects produced by reactor irradiation of commercially pure titanium.

The major scientific impacts of this work, along with scientific firsts, include:

  • Showing for the first time that stored energy correlates directly to radiation-produced defects from a reactor irradiation, at real reactor conditions (not room temperature or colder)
  • Proving that electron microscopy, which is traditionally used to quantify the defects resulting from any type of damage, misses 80% of the smallest defects responsible for most of the actual damage and changes to material properties (see 1st attached figure)
  • Quantifying an unknown population of multiple crystal defects after a major damaging event (one year of irradiation in a nuclear reactor) via a combination of measurements and atomistic simulations
  • Discovering a new multi-stage mechanism of annealing (heat-based healing) of radiation damage (see 2nd attached figure), including the movement of some defects (dislocation loops and network dislocations) to consume smaller point defects and clusters, followed by healing of the dislocations themselves
  • Together with co-funding from the DOE NNSA, developing a new way to forensically reconstruct historical uranium enrichment activities (see 3rd attached figure). This linked the defects caused by very light radiation damage to calorimetry (stored energy and heat) signatures of their existence.

This work also resulted in significant broader impacts, including:

  • The creation of the idea of "stored energy fingerprints" as a holistic measure of damage quantification. This idea, once further developed, could allow workers at nuclear plants and possibly other areas (infrastructure, other power plants) to more quickly and painlessly gauge the level of damage to a material. This in turn can help determine its continued fitness-for-service.
  • The development of a new way to physically measure how much uranium has flowed through a gas centrifuge facility. This, if further developed, could lead to a way to verify nuclear non-proliferation treaties (NPTs), leading to the reduction in global stockpiles of nuclear weapons without violating the sovereignty or proprietary information of IAEA Member States.

Finally, in terms of domestic scientific workforce development, this project resulted in the direct training of two PhD students, one postdoctoral scholar, and four undergraduate researchers who have stayed in the US research and academic enterprises. One has taken a staff scientist job at a US national laboratory, and two have become assistant professors at US universities.

  • A new, two-stage annealing (healing) mechanism discovered by the use of stored energy fingerprints. First, dislocation loops (TEM-visible) move and consume smaller defect clusters (TEM-invisible), followed by annealing of the dislocations themselves.

  • Measuring changes in the enthalpy of recrystallization of irradiated PTFE (Teflon (TM)) reveals the dose to which it was irradiated. Combined with a modeling effort, this lets us reconstruct uranium enrichment to less than 25kg of high-enriched uranium (IAEA-defined weapon-quantity).
    Rachel C. Connick et al., (submitted), 2024.
    Copyrighted
    Michael P Short
    Forensic reconstruction of historical uranium enrichment using stored energy fingerprints
  • Quantifying damage to material via stored energy fingerprints reveals multiple defect populations (top-middle) not visible using electron microscopy during heating (bottom). This approach yields evidence of roughly 5x more defects than electron microscopy can see.
    Charles Hirst et al., Sci. Adv. 8(31):eabn2733 (2022)
